caption_original: The annual North American Christmas Bird Count got thousands of wildlife and outdoor enthusiasts out last month, including more than 120 in the Halifax area. This keen wildlife observer was in search of wintering birds on the picturesque shores of the Halifax Harbour in Nova Scotia.

caption_original:
Ever heard of the Hooded Merganser? It’s just one of the species whose habitat will be protected on the Columbia Valley’s oldest working cattle ranch. 

In partnership with the Nature Conservancy of Canada and others, 4500 hectares of grasslands is now protected as part of the Government of Canada’s Natural Areas Conservation Program. Wetlands on the property also support foraging and breeding habitat for several other waterfowl species, including Barrow’s Goldeneye, Mallard and Ruddy Duck. http://ow.ly/XkES5 

Discover more about Canadian habitat conservation efforts: http://ow.ly/XkEVt

In partnership with the Nature Conservancy of Canada and others, hectares of grasslands is now protected as part of the Government of Canada’s Natural Areas Conservation Program. Wetlands on the property also support foraging and breeding habitat for several other waterfowl species, including Barrow’s Goldeneye, Mallard and Ruddy Duck. Discover more about Canadian habitat conservation efforts:

caption_original:
Does Chignecto Isthmus ring a bell? It’s a narrow strip of land that joins mainland Nova Scotia to New Brunswick and the rest of Canada. It’s also an important habitat for moose, lynx, bobcat and various other species and is an important stopover for migrating waterfowl. 

In partnership with the Nature Conservancy of Canada and other partners, an additional 137 hectares of the Moose Sex Corridor is now protected as part of the Government of Canada’s Natural Areas Conservation Program, totaling 1,227 hectares of protected land. Discover more about Canadian habitat conservation efforts: http://ow.ly/X1p9k

In partnership with the Nature Conservancy of Canada and other partners, an additional hectares of the Moose Sex Corridor is now protected as part of the Government of Canada’s Natural Areas Conservation Program, totaling ,227 hectares of protected land.
